newsitem.title: GERMANY: BASF denies dividend payout over 1 bln dmk.
newsitem.headline: BASF denies dividend payout over 1 bln dmk.

text.p: German chemicals company BASF AG on Wednesday denied a magazine report which said its chief financial officer Dietrich Kley had predicted the group's total dividend payout would rise to more than one billion marks for 1996.
A BASF spokesman said in response to a Reuter enquiry that Kley did not make that statement in an interview with "Das Wertpapier" magazine.

"What is correct is that Mr Kley confirmed earlier statements that BASF is seeking a higher share price level which would then have to be correspondingly underpinned with dividend," the spokesman said.
Das Wertpapier reported that Kley had said BASF would for the first time distribute more than one billion marks ($626.5 million) in dividends to its shareholders for the 1996 year.

The BASF spokesman said a dividend total of one billion marks would mean a payout of 1.64 marks per share, up from 1.40 marks for 1995. "Most banks currently estimate our dividend for 1996 will be 1.60 marks," the spokesman said.
BASF chief executive Juergen Strube last November hinted the company might announce a higher dividend by saying shareholders might have reason to celebrate the payout.
The BASF spokesman confirmed a statement made by Kley to the magazine that BASF did not at present plan any takeovers in Germany.
Kley denied that BASF was interested in buying chemicals and metals company Degussa which like BASF has a large share of the vitamins market.
The interview with Das Wertpapier was conducted on December 27 last year.
